messageBody:
Applauds for wanting to teach students the right way from the
beginning!! (BTW: If you want to really teach OO, why not use
Smalltalk? Squeak is free and fantastic! -- Sorry for the shameless
plug.)

I just did a quick "trawl" through blueJ (not very impressed I must
say!). If it's open source, it shouldn't be hard to integrate JUnit.
All you would need to do is implement a sub-menu to the Tools menu or
something that would allow you to execute a TestRunner (most likely in
another VM). The real key is whether or not you can get the source.

Actually, I think that Eric's suggestion is a valid one for this "IDE"
(if it can be called that). If you are really concerned about
classpaths and other issues that happen to be inherit in Java (and while
you are teaching Java, why not teach about its 'issues'), you could
easily write a script that would run tests for them, setting up the
classpath auto-magically. Heck, you could even write a little app or
script that will download it for them, install it to the directory of
the students choice, set the environment variables, and then generate
the build.xml for them. That would at most take a day to do something
so simple (unless you are running on Mac or Windows, then it's easily
1.5 days). :) There are many solutions to your problem, choose the one
with which you are most comfortable.

=jason

On Tue, 2002-07-16 at 09:26, daviddench wrote: --- In junit@y..., Eric
Heikkila <ericheikkila@y...> wrote:
> Regardless of whether it's built in or not, it's
> fairly easy to use JUnit. Just import the files, set
> up the classpath, etc., and start writing tests.
>
> If you need any specific help or examples, drop me an
> email at:
>
> ericheikkila@y...
>
> -Eric
>
Thanks for the offer Eric. I am familiar with JUnit, but the criteria
here is not to overload this particular group of students too quickly.
I want to use the very simple BlueJ environment to nanny the students
( for a variety of reasons ) but also introduce unit testing very
quickly via TDD. It would be nicer if UT was relatively seamless at
first.

David
